boat.name: Ariel
boat.full_description:
Ariel is a cutter from that doyen of yawl designers, Albert Strange. In actual fact she is sister ship to Cherub III which was designed to have a transom stern, but was built with a canoe stern, although still a yawl. In 1930 another yawl rigged version, Galatea, was also built. Ariel probably remains Strange's only cutter.

Her early history is well documented as her first owner JB Kirkpatrick wrote extensively about her in Yachting Monthly between 1925 and 1933. One trip (engineless and single-handed!) was from Heybridge to the Channel Islands and back in a week. She also sailed to Spain across Biscay as detailed in Kirkpatrick's book "Little Ship Wanderings" (1933).

In 1930 she was second in The Little Ship Club's inaugural Brightlingsea to Ostend race. This was their first ever handicap race.

In 1998 she was substantially restored by Peter and Jim Maynard. This included a redesigned sail plan by Gayle Heard which has radically altered her performance.
